Torneko no Daiboken: Fushigi no Dungeon.Title: Torneko no Daiboken: Fushigi no Dungeon

Teleglitch.Title: Teleglitch
Teleglitch.Notes:
2D top-down shooter with line-of-sight shadows. A randomly generated military
research base full of repurposed ex-personell is the setting for you, your guns,
your high explosives, and whatever other weapons/augmentations you can craft.

Dungeon of Doom.Title: Dungeon of Doom
Dungeon of Doom.Notes: Released commercially in 1987 as *The Dungeon Revealed*.

Larn.Title: Larn
Larn.Notes: Original version of *Larn* remains part of the NetBSD games collection.[4]

UnReal World.Title: UnReal World
UnReal World.Notes:
Graphical roguelike set in the far north during the late Iron-Age. It's
open-ended and emphasized on survival in the harsh ancient wilderness.

Rogue Legacy.Title: Rogue Legacy
Rogue Legacy.Notes:
2D side-scrolling Dungeon crawl, RPG. Players are able to collect gold,
food and potions while combating enemies. Fights are random. Each character
has its own unique abilities. Characters level up and change every time
player dies.

Ancient Domains of Mystery.Title: Ancient Domains of Mystery
Ancient Domains of Mystery.Platform: AMI, BeOS, DOS, LIN, OS2, OSX, WIN

Sword of the Stars: The Pit.Title: Sword of the Stars: The Pit
Sword of the Stars: The Pit.Notes:
Turn based, 2D Dungeon crawl, RPG based in the Sword of the Stars universe.
Players are able to collect equipment, weapons, armor, and ingredients for
crafting. Explore 30 levels and death is permanent.

Infinite Space III: Sea of Stars.Title: Infinite Space III: Sea of Stars
Infinite Space III: Sea of Stars.Notes: 3D graphics, sound and music; plays to completion in 20-45 minutes.

Dark Cloud.Title: Dark Cloud
Dark Cloud.Notes:
Also included a city-building aspect, making it not purely a roguelike,
though dungeons did include a roguelike engine.

Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Explorers of Da.Title: Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Explorers of Darkness

Smart Kobold.Title: Smart Kobold
Smart Kobold.Notes:
A "seven-day roguelike" that was selected for demonstration at IndieCade, E3
2010. It attempts to implement a high level of artificial intelligence for
a single type of enemy.[10]

Lost Labyrinth.Title: Lost Labyrinth
Lost Labyrinth.Notes:
"Zelda style" gameplay, graphics and sound; plays to its conclusion in
10–40 minutes.

Slaves to Armok II: Dwarf Fortress.Title: Slaves to Armok II: Dwarf Fortress

Tales (or Troubles) of Middle Earth.Title: Tales (or Troubles) of Middle Earth
Tales (or Troubles) of Middle Earth.Notes:
Based on the PernBand variant of Angband, and thus on The Lord of the Rings.
Author no longer maintains it, but a separate maintenance branch repository
exists.[5]

Dungeon Hack.Title: Dungeon Hack
Dungeon Hack.Notes:
Features a pseudo-3D game screen based on SSI's *Eye of the Beholder*
series. It uses the rules mechanics of *AD&D* 2nd Edition.

Wizards Encounters.Title: Wizards Encounters
Wizards Encounters.Notes:
Turn based role playing game based on the Wizards universe. Players are
able to collect money, items, weapons and armor. Fights are random and
death is permanent.

Angband.Title: Angband
Angband.Notes: Based heavily on *The Lord of the Rings*.

Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Blue Rescue Tea.Title: Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Blue Rescue Team

FTL: Faster Than Light.Title: FTL: Faster Than Light
FTL: Faster Than Light.Notes:
2D Dungeon exploration styled after space travel. Players move from system
to system avoiding a trailing horde of enemies as they participate in
side-quests, with the ultimate goal of entering the last area.

Moraff's Revenge.Title: Moraff's Revenge
Moraff's Revenge.Notes: One of the earliest 3D, first-person perspective role-playing video games.

Tao's Adventure: Curse of the Demon Seal.Title: Tao's Adventure: Curse of the Demon Seal

Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Explorers of Sk.Title: Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Explorers of Sky

Z.H.P. Unlosing Ranger VS Darkdeath Evil.Title: Z.H.P. Unlosing Ranger VS Darkdeath Evilman

Don't Starve.Title: Don't Starve
Don't Starve.Notes:
2D action-adventure. Players are able to harvest plants, build traps to
catch animals and craft items. Fights and levels are random and death is
permanent.[15]

Beneath Apple Manor.Title: Beneath Apple Manor
Beneath Apple Manor.Notes:
One of the earliest commercial Apple II games. It predates Rogue, and was
much simpler, but supported a low resolution graphical display in addition
to the text version. Was ported to the IBM PC in 1983.[1]

Tower of Guns.Title: Tower of Guns
Tower of Guns.Notes:
Single player game described as "Quake-roguelike" for its randomly
generated levels.[17]

Dragon Quest: Shonen Yangus to Fushigi n.Title: Dragon Quest: Shonen Yangus to Fushigi no Dungeon

The Binding of Isaac.Title: The Binding of Isaac (video game)
The Binding of Isaac.Notes:
2D Dungeon exploration without save points inspired by The Legend of Zelda,
but with semi-randomly accessed floors with exclusive features that have
randomly generated rooms of various types potentially including random
items.

Rogue.Title: Rogue
Rogue.Notes: Inspired the genre as a whole.

Nightmare of Druaga: Fushigino Dungeon.Title: Nightmare of Druaga: Fushigino Dungeon
Nightmare of Druaga: Fushigino Dungeon.Notes: Sequel to *The Blue Crystal Rod* for SNES.

Izuna 2: The Unemployed Ninja Returns.Title: Izuna 2: The Unemployed Ninja Returns
Izuna 2: The Unemployed Ninja Returns.Notes: Sequel to *Izuna: Legend of the Unemployed Ninja*

Deadly Dungeons.Title: Deadly Dungeons
Deadly Dungeons.Notes:
3D Dungeon exploration with randomly generated floors, items, and
creatures. Movement is tile-based. First-person roguelike [12] gameplay
similar to Dungeon Hack.

The Sorcerer's Cave.Title: The Sorcerer's Cave
The Sorcerer's Cave.Notes:
Based on Donnelly's "roguelike" boardgames, The Sorcerer's Cave (1978) and Mystic
Wood published by Avalon Hill in 1980

Torneko: The Last Hope.Title: Torneko: The Last Hope
Torneko: The Last Hope.Notes: Sequel to *Torneko no Daiboken: Fushigi no Dungeon*.

Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Explorers of Ti.Title: Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Explorers of Time

Tales of Maj'Eyal.Title: Tales of Maj'Eyal
Tales of Maj'Eyal.Notes:
Graphical rewrite of the author's earlier ToME (video game). Turn based
role playing game based on its own fantasy universe. Players unlock most
classes, story threads are available, and elements have been taken from
MMOs to significantly change the combat.

Spelunky.Title: Spelunky
Spelunky.Notes:
2D action-adventure platformer without save points that has four
increasingly difficult areas with exclusive features that are divided into
multiple randomly generated caves of which each one might contain a further
unique secret.

TowerClimb (Beta).Title: TowerClimb (Beta)
TowerClimb (Beta).Notes:
An unforgiving proceedurally generated platformer, in which players must
climb/jump/fly and swim up through increasingly difficult levels. The game
is divided into multiple sections each with their own unique theme and
challenges.[14]

Dungeons of Dredmor.Title: Dungeons of Dredmor
Dungeons of Dredmor.Notes: Tile-based movement with rudimentary graphics and a sense of humour.[13]

Dungeons of the Unforgiven.Title: Dungeons of the Unforgiven
Dungeons of the Unforgiven.Notes:
The final of the series that began with *Moraff's Revenge* and continued
with *Moraff's World*. It is very unforgiving indeed on "I can handle
anything" difficulty.

Super Lotsa Added Stuff Hack - Extended.Title: Super Lotsa Added Stuff Hack - Extended Magic

Weird Worlds: Return to Infinite Space.Title: Weird Worlds: Return to Infinite Space
Weird Worlds: Return to Infinite Space.Notes:
Full graphics, sound and music; sequel to *Strange Adventures in Infinite
Space*; plays to its conclusion in less than 30 minutes.

Doom, the Roguelike.Title: Doom, the Roguelike
Doom, the Roguelike.Notes: Based on the *Doom* series by id Software.

Dark Chronicle / Dark Cloud 2.Title: Dark Chronicle / Dark Cloud 2
Dark Chronicle / Dark Cloud 2.Notes:
Much like its predecessor, Dark Cloud, it wasn't a pure roguelike,
including world-building aspects, though dungeons remained roguelike.

Alphaman.Title: Alphaman
Alphaman.Notes: Features "elaborate use of colors and the extended IBM character set"

Risk of Rain.Title: Risk of Rain
Risk of Rain.Notes:
2D side-scrolling action platformer; a single play through goes through six
levels that are randomly selected from pre-generated layouts but with
randomized object placement, and the game's difficulty increases based on
how long the player remains alive.

Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Red Rescue Team.Title: Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Red Rescue Team

Sword of Fargoal.Title: Sword of Fargoal
Sword of Fargoal.Notes: Based on *Gammaquest II* by the same author.

Links: http://rover.ebay.com/rover/1/711-53200-19255-0/1?icep_ff3=9&pub=5574933636&toolid=10001&campid=5336728181&customid=&icep_uq=Chocobo no Fushigina Dungeon Final Fantasy Wonderswan Bandai Japan&icep_sellerId=&icep_ex_kw=&icep_sortBy=12&icep_catId=&icep_minPrice=&icep_maxPrice=&ipn=psmain&icep_vectorid=229466&kwid=902099&mtid=824&kw=lg
Chocobo no Fushigina Dungeon.Title: Chocobo no Fushigina Dungeon

Omega.Title: Omega
Omega.Notes: Features a rich, persistent and quirky world and multiple endings.

Fushigi no Dungeon: Fūrai no Shiren 2: O.Title: Fushigi no Dungeon: Fūrai no Shiren 2: Oni Shūrai! Siren-jō!

Izuna: Legend of the Unemployed Ninja.Title: Izuna: Legend of the Unemployed Ninja

Moria.Title: Moria
Moria.Notes:
Based heavily on *The Lord of the Rings*. Later port (*Umoria*) became the
basis of *Angband*. Influenced the preliminary design of Blizzard's *Diablo*
.[3]
Moria.Developer: Robert Alan Koeneke & Jimmey Wayne Todd

Strange Adventures In Infinite Space.Title: Strange Adventures In Infinite Space
Strange Adventures In Infinite Space.Notes: Full graphics, sound and music; plays to completion in 20 minutes or less.

WazHack.Title: WazHack
WazHack.Notes:
Turn based, 2D side-scrollingDungeon crawl, RPG. Players are able to
collect equipment, weapons, armor, potions, and scrolls while combating
enemies and starvation. Fights and levels are random and death is permanent.

Not the Robots.Title: Not the Robots
Not the Robots.Notes:
From their Steam Store Page: "Not The Robots is this year’s most exciting
Roguelike Stealth Furniture Eating Simulator. It’s a game with random
levels, permadeath, and the goal of eating furniture. Same furniture is
also your stealth cover. "
